Content isn't written; it's assembled. Then updated.

text: Anyone got any good attribution models for content activities? We currently only measure last touch and this obviously skews the numbers towards BOFU content. :face_with_monocle:

elements.text: Anyone got any good attribution models for content activities? We currently only measure last touch and this obviously skews the numbers towards BOFU content.

text: Multi-touch attribution is definitely the way to go. Or run multiple models at the same time, if possible.

elements.text: Multi-touch attribution is definitely the way to go. Or run multiple models at the same time, if possible.

text: I'm writing up a new Medium piece on yearly content calendars. Are they a thing of the past? Would love to hear a few varied viewpoints to be quoted. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I'm writing up a new Medium piece on yearly content calendars. Are they a thing of the past? Would love to hear a few varied viewpoints to be quoted.

text: What happens when your year gets interrupted and you write something reactive or based on a trending topic? What happens if you can't fill a whole year?

elements.text: What happens when your year gets interrupted and you write something reactive or based on a trending topic? What happens if you can't fill a whole year?

text: You can weight different points of a multi-touch model to get the balance your team needs. This article has a good explanation of some different options: <https://www.marketingevolution.com/marketing-essentials/multi-touch-attribution>

attachments.title: What is Multi-Touch Attribution? | Marketing Evolution
attachments.text: Multi-Touch Attribution determines which touchpoints deliver the most ROI in your marketing campaigns. Combine MTA with other data sets to make informed decisions on which channels and campaigns to capitalize on to drive business forward.
attachments.fallback: What is Multi-Touch Attribution? | Marketing Evolution

elements.text: You can weight different points of a multi-touch model to get the balance your team needs. This article has a good explanation of some different options:

text:
No, they're the future! I have been advising my clients to create 6-months or 12-month editorial calendars with topics, schedules, and ownership of roles detailed on the calendar. The trick is to stay flexible if you need to make changes (say because of a pandemic) during that time.

Too many content teams are on the content treadmill scrambling to figure out what to publish every week!

elements.text:
No, they're the future! I have been advising my clients to create 6-months or 12-month editorial calendars with topics, schedules, and ownership of roles detailed on the calendar. The trick is to stay flexible if you need to make changes (say because of a pandemic) during that time.

Too many content teams are on the content treadmill scrambling to figure out what to publish every week!

text: What happens if the CMO leaves (18 month average spell in 2019)? I think 3-6 months of well planned content is a better approach than a yearly content calendar.

elements.text: What happens if the CMO leaves (18 month average spell in 2019)? I think 3-6 months of well planned content is a better approach than a yearly content calendar.

text: IMHO first- or last-touch models are outdated at this point and completely ignore the impact content has at all stages of the buyer’s journey. There’s no way to know if you’re impacting revenue if you’re only attributing value to one of those two touches.

elements.text: IMHO first- or last-touch models are outdated at this point and completely ignore the impact content has at all stages of the buyer’s journey. There’s no way to know if you’re impacting revenue if you’re only attributing value to one of those two touches.

text: <@UJJFDTN8G> actually working with a client where that happened. Consulting with marketing team and new CMO is reevaluating everything. But, at least they have something to work from. New CMO will likely modify, not scrap current direction.

elements.text: actually working with a client where that happened. Consulting with marketing team and new CMO is reevaluating everything. But, at least they have something to work from. New CMO will likely modify, not scrap current direction.

text: I tend to be on Dom's side because of how Covid completely screwed up content plans for most folks. I lean towards quarterly content planning myself.

elements.text: I tend to be on Dom's side because of how Covid completely screwed up content plans for most folks. I lean towards quarterly content planning myself.

text: I'd agree the size if the team is important. But, I think it's easier to spend 1-2 days planning (whether a quarter, 6 mos, or 12 mos) and spend the rest executing and promoting the content.

elements.text: I'd agree the size if the team is important. But, I think it's easier to spend 1-2 days planning (whether a quarter, 6 mos, or 12 mos) and spend the rest executing and promoting the content.

elements.text: you can plan a 12 month content calendar in 2 days?

text: Yes, it may not be written in stone but enough to use as a starting point. I have worked with some clients who only wanted to initially publish weekly so you're only coming up with ~50 topics.

elements.text: Yes, it may not be written in stone but enough to use as a starting point. I have worked with some clients who only wanted to initially publish weekly so you're only coming up with ~50 topics.

text: A little discussion with the client and you can flesh out ideas and see what needs to be tweaked.

elements.text: A little discussion with the client and you can flesh out ideas and see what needs to be tweaked.

text: Of course, the more content you're producing, the more time it takes to plan the calendar.

elements.text: Of course, the more content you're producing, the more time it takes to plan the calendar.

text:
Speaking specifically to the COVID of it all, we've had at least one client that I'm aware of at Animalz that had been planning on sticking to a very calendar-driven strategy this year but has since had to abandon that because conditions on the ground are shifting so rapidly that it's impossible to plan in advance the way you need to in order to make a calendar-driven strategy work.

Just to use one example, think about tax day: Everybody was hustling to prepare tax-related content in, what, February/March? And whoops - now taxes aren't due until July, and all the tax-related stuff you published three months ago is already stale. Sorry, everybody?

Now, as with a lot of things COVID-related, it's unclear whether this is a short-term aberration or a true paradigm shift in the way brands approach content. And I'm never really one to pretend to be a fortune teller. But if you forced me, I'd be willing to wager we're going to see people investing *even* more in evergreen and way more in immediately timely stuff for at least the next... 12-18 months or so.

elements.text:

Just to use one example, think about tax day: Everybody was hustling to prepare tax-related content in, what, February/March? And whoops - now taxes aren't due until July, and all the tax-related stuff you published three months ago is already stale. Sorry, everybody?

Now, as with a lot of things COVID-related, it's unclear whether this is a short-term aberration or a true paradigm shift in the way brands approach content. And I'm never really one to pretend to be a fortune teller. But if you forced me, I'd be willing to wager we're going to see people investing
even
more in evergreen and way more in immediately timely stuff for at least the next... 12-18 months or so.

text: <@UJ48Q1HAP> was the industry your client operates in heavily affected by COVID? Curious as I'm doing research on how SaaS marketing has been impacted.

elements.text: was the industry your client operates in heavily affected by COVID? Curious as I'm doing research on how SaaS marketing has been impacted.

text: <@UUVS5HWMB> They're B2B, so it doesn't seem like they've been impacted so much as some of their customers closer to the direct effects of the pandemic (travel, hospitality, etc.) have been impacted. But the thing about being B2B with a fairly broad target audience is, you can always go get customers who are doing well to replace the customers who churn due to hard times (as tough as that is for the businesses that have been impacted).

text:
Hey folks! :wave: Need little help.

I'm trying to understand what's your content strategy at every stage of the funnel: TOFU, MOFU & BOFU. 

Essentially what type of content do you put out at every stage of the customer journey and why? 

TIA! :crossed_fingers:

elements.text: Hey folks!

Need little help.

I'm trying to understand what's your content strategy at every stage of the funnel: TOFU, MOFU & BOFU. 

Essentially what type of content do you put out at every stage of the customer journey and why? 

TIA!

text:
I tend to stick to quarterly planning for content. Things change too quickly to plan a full 6-12 months.

However, the plan for each quarter is guided, at a high level, by annual "themes." From quarter to quarter, we approach those themes from different angles and evolve the messaging as things change.

Topic-wise, we plan for a mix of content to support demand gen campaigns (short-term) with evergreen keyword-focused topics (long-term).

elements.text:

However, the plan for each quarter is guided, at a high level, by annual "themes." From quarter to quarter, we approach those themes from different angles and evolve the messaging as things change.

Topic-wise, we plan for a mix of content to support demand gen campaigns (short-term) with evergreen keyword-focused topics (long-term).

text: Thanks all! To be clear, I wasn't planning on making them do outreach <@UUXMCJQ15>. I was going to focus on the B2B Content-Based Networking approach and ask for a backlink after creating content about specific companies and influencers on our Target Account List. My last hire started as a content specialist - social and writing. She excelled in social but didn't find long-form SEO writing interesting. I'm trying to prevent that from happening with this hire. Thanks for the job examples - <@UJG9WTEKG> & <@UPWK0KJE9> - they are very helpful!

text: Looking for HR/People Ops professionals who can share what their companies have done to prioritize employee health during COVID. *Survey responses needed by EOD Tuesday August 18th.* <https://forms.gle/VNqjVMpmQQ3AGzxJA>

attachments.title: Survey: Prioritizing Employee Health in the Post-COVID Era
attachments.text: We're working on an article for <http://Uptickapp.com|Uptickapp.com> that will focus on how different companies are supporting their teams and prioritizing employee health during the COVID-19 crisis. This could refer to mental health, physical health, and overall well-being. We're interested in how you've adapted to the post-COVID era through things such as: • Changes to health benefits • Updating sick day policies (i.e. additional sick days, expanding sick days to cover time spent caring for a sick loved one, etc) • Mental health support • Work-from-home stipends • Flexible work schedules/shorter work weeks • Any other employee health-focused initiatives All quotes will be attributed with a backlink to your site. Thank you for sharing your insights!
attachments.fallback: Google Docs: Survey: Prioritizing Employee Health in the Post-COVID Era

text: My former company received a cease and desist from a competitor because our content was “deceitful.” It was not, they just didn’t love the comparison. Our legal team recommended we hold our ground as there was no legal basis for the compliant. The competitor eventually dropped it. It was a scare tactic.
